Task involves attributing social events to self or others (internal vs external attributions) and examines self-responsibility and self-serving bias, which are core social-cognitive processes; meets both I1 and I2.

Stimuli involve friends and interpersonal scenarios but the contrast tests attributional responsibility (internal vs external) rather than directly measuring affiliation/attachment per se; does not clearly meet the task requirement to measure affiliation/attachment.

The task involves reading and attributing causality for social events rather than measuring social communication (e.g., facial or non‑facial communicative exchange); does not meet the social communication criteria.
The contrast probes self-responsibility and agency (internal attributions), directly assessing perception/understanding of the self; satisfies both I1 and I2.

External attributions (attributing events to others or situation) probe representation and understanding of others' responsibility and intentionality, matching perception/understanding of others; satisfies both I1 and I2.
Task involves attribution of causality for social events (internal vs external attributions); this directly measures social processing (self/other understanding).
Task assesses causal attributions for social events, not measures of affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding; contrast (External>Internal) does not index affiliation/attachment.
The task is about causal attribution (self vs other responsibility) rather than receptive/expressive social communication (e.g., facial/gaze/affect recognition or production).
The specific contrast is External > Internal, which emphasizes attribution to others/situation rather than self-perception/agency; therefore it does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
External > Internal contrasts attribution to others/situations vs self and therefore directly probes perception and understanding of others' responsibility/intentionality.

The task explicitly involves social causal attributions (self vs other responsibility) and investigates the self-serving bias — clearly a social processing task. It measures processes of perceiving and interpreting social information about self and others.

Although stimuli reference friends/neighbors, the task targets causal attribution and self-serving bias rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of attachment or bonding). Therefore it does not meet criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

The paradigm does not probe social communication (facial/exchange behaviors, receptive/expressive communication). It focuses on attributional judgments, so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The analysis directly probes perception and understanding of the self (self-responsibility, agency, self-serving attributions), satisfying the self-related criteria.
The contrasts involve attributing causation to others (external-personal) and thus involve perception/understanding of others’ responsibility/intentionality; the analysis measures this construct.

Task involves social attribution decisions about events involving friends (internal vs external attributions) and measures social cognition (self-responsibility and attributional bias). Satisfies social-related task and measures social processing.
Although stimuli involve friends, the task measures attributional style/self-serving bias rather than affiliation or attachment processes per se; it does not target bonding/attachment measures.

The paradigm does not measure social communication (facial/exchange behaviors or receptive/expressive communication); it tests causal attributions about social events rather than communication processes.
The contrast includes internal attributions of negative events (self-blame) and internal vs external attributions, directly indexing perception/understanding of the self and agency.
The non-self-serving contrast includes external attribution of positive events (attributing events to others), which indexes perception and understanding of others' responsibility/intentionality.

The task involves social learning about cooperators and defectors and compares affective (cooperator/defector) faces to neutral faces, directly measuring social processing.

The paradigm manipulates cooperation (cooperators) versus neutral/defector partners and assesses responses to cooperative social bonds; this contrasts captures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The analysis involves perception of faces and learned social information (cooperation/defection), fitting social communication (reception of facial/social cues) and uses cooperation/competition paradigms.
This analysis concerns perception and evaluation of others (cooperators/defectors), not self-related processing; it does not meet criteria for Perception and Understanding of Self.
The contrast probes representations and evaluations of others’ social/moral status (cooperators, defectors, intentionality), directly measuring perception and understanding of others.
Task involves learned social judgments about cooperators vs neutral faces (social cognition), directly measuring social processing.
Contrast probes cooperative behavior and social bonds (cooperators vs neutral), matching affiliation/attachment (cooperation) criteria.
Analysis involves perception of facial stimuli whose social meaning (cooperation) was learned; fits Social Communication (receptive facial communication/cooperation).
Analysis examines perception of others' moral/social status (cooperator vs neutral faces), not self-related processes or judgments about the self.
Directly assesses representations and judgments about others' traits/behavior (cooperators vs neutral), satisfying perception/understanding of others.
Task involves learned social judgments (cooperation vs defection) and perception of social agents; contrast (defector vs neutral faces) measures social processing.
Task examines cooperation and social bonding/reward (cooperators vs defectors), matching affiliation/attachment constructs.
Study uses facial stimuli and implicit social communication cues (face perception tied to cooperative/defective behavior); contrast measures social communication via face-based social information.
Study focuses on perception/learning about others' moral status and intentions, not on self-related processing.
Contrast interrogates representations and judgments about others' traits and intentions (cooperator/defector), meeting perception-of-others criteria.

Task involves social learning (Prisoner’s Dilemma) and perception of moral status of faces; the contrast (intentional vs nonintentional cooperators) measures social processing related to judgments about others’ social behavior and intentionality.

The task explicitly tests cooperation and social bonding (cooperators vs neutral/defectors); contrast addresses affiliation-related processing (responses to cooperators, and intentionality modulating social evaluation).
The analysis involves processing facial stimuli with socially relevant learned information (perception/reception of facial communication and social cues), satisfying social communication criteria.

The contrast concerns perception and evaluation of others (cooperators) and attribution of intentionality, not self-related perception or judgments, so it does not meet Perception/Understanding of Self.
The contrast probes representations about others’ social behavior and intentionality (understanding others’ moral status), directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast 'Cooperation versus independent' is a social interaction task probing social cognition (cooperation) and compares it to independent play; it therefore measures social processing (self/other monitoring, mentalizing, social reward).

The task explicitly involves cooperation (an affiliation/attachment-related interaction) and the contrast isolates cooperative (affiliative) behavior versus independent play, meeting the affiliation/attachment criteria.

Cooperation trials require exchange of socially relevant information and coordination with another agent (example task listed in criteria), and the contrast targets social-communicative interaction versus independent play.

The paradigm probes self-related processes (agency, self–other monitoring) during cooperation versus independent play; the contrast examines perception/understanding of self-related agency and monitoring.

The cooperation condition requires representing and predicting the other's actions/intentions (mentalizing, understanding others), and the contrast isolates those processes relative to independent play.

The contrast pits a social interaction condition (competition) against independent play. This directly assesses social cognition (mentalizing, self–other monitoring, social stance), satisfying both criteria.

Affiliation/attachment annotation lists cooperation and competition as example tasks. The competition vs independent contrast examines social interaction and related affiliative/competitive dynamics, meeting the inclusion criteria.
Competition involves exchange of socially relevant information and strategic interaction; the contrast measures social communicative/interactive processes, matching the inclusion criteria.
The study highlights agency, self–other monitoring and self-related processing in competition vs independent contrasts, thus measuring perception/understanding of self (agency), satisfying criteria.
Competition requires anticipating and attributing intentions to others (mentalizing). The contrast probes perception and understanding of others, meeting both inclusion criteria.
The contrast directly manipulates social interaction (cooperation vs competition) and measures social processing (self–other monitoring, mentalizing, reward in social context).
Cooperation versus competition probes affiliation/attachment-related processes (cooperation as social bonding/reward) and explicitly matches the example tasks.
The task involves interpersonal exchange and coordinating actions with another person (cooperation/competition), meeting criteria for social communication.
Analysis examines agency and self–other monitoring (sense of agency, self/other distinction) relevant to Perception and Understanding of Self.
Task requires reasoning about others' intentions and actions (mentalizing, predicting opponent/cooperator behavior), satisfying Perception and Understanding of Others.
The task directly involves social interaction (cooperation vs competition) and the contrasts measure social processing (self–other monitoring, mentalizing, reward in social context).
Cooperation vs competition directly probes affiliation-related processes (cooperation as affiliative/social bonding) and the contrast isolates affiliation/attachment-related neural responses.

The task involves exchange of socially relevant information and interactive behavior (cooperation/competition), matching examples in the inclusion criteria and measuring social communication processes.
The analyses examine self-related processes (sense of agency, self–other merging/distinction) in cooperation and competition, satisfying criteria for perception/understanding of self.
Competition in particular engages mentalizing and representation of others' intentions (medial prefrontal activation); the contrasts assess perception/understanding of others.

Task involves evaluative judgments of self-conscious social emotions (guilt, embarrassment) and explicitly invokes theory-of-mind/social cognition; thus it measures social processing.

Participants made first-person evaluative judgments about guilt/embarrassment (self-conscious emotions), engaging self-monitoring/awareness processes; thus it measures perception/understanding of self.

Task directly involves self–other social discrimination (viewing self vs a highly familiar other) and measures social cognitive processing related to perception and understanding of self and others.
The task contrasts self vs a familiar other but does not specifically probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, relationship quality, or loved‑one vs stranger comparisons).
The paradigm involves reception of facial information (face recognition/discrimination) between self and familiar other, fitting Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
The contrast explicitly targets perception and understanding of the self (self‑face recognition), satisfying the self‑perception construct.
The analysis contrasts self vs a familiar other and examines neural responses to the other condition (social representations), thus addressing perception and understanding of others.
Task contrasts self vs familiar other faces and examines neural correlates of self/other perception—this is a social-related task and measures social processing (self and other representations).

Although a highly familiar friend was used as a control, the study was designed to probe self-recognition rather than to measure affiliation or attachment specifically (no attachment scales or loved-vs-stranger manipulation).
The task requires facial perception and discrimination (self vs other), which falls under reception of facial communication and thus social communication.
Self-face recognition directly probes perception and understanding of the self (self as object), satisfying criteria for self-related perception.

Contrast examines perception of faces (distracter/unknown faces) versus scrambled baseline; this is a social-related task measuring social perception, so meets I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

Task involves reception of facial information (face recognition/processing of others), which falls under social communication (receptive facial communication).
Contrast does not involve self-related processing (self-face vs familiar face contrasts would, but distracter vs null does not).
Contrast directly measures perception of others' faces (unknown/distracter faces) versus baseline, satisfying criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast of personally familiar face vs unknown distracter is a social task involving perception and recognition of socially relevant faces and understanding of self/other relations; thus measures social processing.
Comparing a personally familiar (fraternity brother) face to an unknown face taps affiliation/attachment-related processing (personal familiarity/close social bond), so meets criteria.
This contrast assesses reception of facial information (recognition of familiar vs unfamiliar faces), which falls under social communication (reception of facial communication).
The contrast compares familiar other to distracter (unknown) faces and does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Familiar vs unknown face contrast indexes representations and recognition of others (their identity/familiarity), meeting perception/understanding of others criteria.
Task involves self-face recognition contrasted with distracter (unknown) faces, which is a social-related task measuring perception/processing of self in social context. Satisfies both criteria.

Directly measures perception/understanding of the self via self-face recognition (self vs distracter), satisfying the self-perception criteria.

The contrast (familiar minus self) involves recognizing self and personally familiar others, which is a social-related task measuring social processing (perception/understanding of self and others).

Although the familiar stimulus is a fraternity brother, the analysis contrasts familiar vs self and does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment or bonding; no attachment-specific task or measure is used.
The task requires facial recognition (reception of facial communication) of self vs personally familiar other, meeting criteria for social communication.
The contrast directly assesses self-face recognition and thus perception/understanding of self.
The contrast also involves processing a personally familiar other, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.

Task contrasts self-face with personally familiar faces, which is a social-related task involving perception and interpretation of self in a social context (self vs familiar). Both inclusion criteria are met.

The contrast centers on self vs familiar-face recognition rather than measuring affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding per se. Although the familiar face is a fraternity brother, the task does not assess attachment/affiliation constructs explicitly.
The task involves facial recognition and discrimination (receptive facial communication) between self and familiar faces, meeting social communication criteria.
The analysis directly contrasts self-face against familiar-face, indexing processes of self-perception and self-recognition, satisfying the self-perception criteria.
The contrast involves recognition of a familiar other (personally familiar face) and thus taps perception/understanding of others, meeting the inclusion criteria.

The contrast ‘ToM’ − ‘Physical 1’ involves theory-of-mind (mentalizing) processing, a core social process; it uses social cartoon stimuli to infer others' mental states, meeting both I1 and I2.
The task probes mentalizing and empathy but not affiliation/attachment (no measures of close bonds, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Theory of Mind contrast explicitly measures understanding and reasoning about others' mental states (mentalizing), directly satisfying both inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.
The contrast ‘Empathy − Physical 2’ explicitly requires inferring the protagonist's emotions and engages empathic/social-cognitive processing; it is a social-related task measuring social processing.
The task probes empathic inference about emotional states, but does not measure affiliation/attachment, relationship bonding, or cooperation-specific constructs required for this annotation.

Although stimuli involve social scenes and emotion, the contrast targets empathic inference rather than exchange of social information or communicative behavior; it does not meet the social communication construct as defined.
The contrast measures understanding of others' emotions (empathy), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency.

The empathy contrast directly assesses representation and reasoning about others' emotional states (Understanding Mental States subconstruct), satisfying the criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The conjunction analysis examines Theory of Mind and empathy using cartoon tasks that require perceiving and inferring others' mental and emotional states—clearly a social-processing task. Satisfies both specifying a social-related task and measuring social processing.

Empathy condition requires perceiving and interpreting others' emotions (receptive social communication). The contrasts measure social-communication-related processes.

The contrasts explicitly probe perception and understanding of others (Theory of Mind, empathy), matching the Understanding Mental States subconstruct.

The task contrasts Theory of Mind and Empathy conditions—both are canonical social-cognitive tasks involving perception and understanding of others’ mental and emotional states. The contrast measures social processing directly.
The task probes ToM and empathy (inferring intentions/emotions) but does not assess affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, or loved vs stranger contrasts).

The paradigm assesses mental state and emotional inference from cartoons rather than explicit social communication behaviors (facial/gaze/expressive production or reception). It does not target the defined social communication subconstructs.
The contrasts focus on understanding others (ToM, empathy) rather than self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge).

The ToM and Empathy conditions explicitly require representing and reasoning about others’ mental and emotional states, matching the ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ construct (including Understanding Mental States).

The contrasts compare Theory of Mind and Empathy versus physical causality controls—both are core social processes (perception and inference about others). Satisfies I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures Social Processing).

The task probes ToM and empathy (inferring mental/emotional states) rather than affiliation, bonding, or relationship/attachment processes. Does not meet the inclusion criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

The paradigm assesses inference of mental/emotional states from cartoons rather than receptive/expressive social communication (e.g., face/gaze exchange, communication between parties). It does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrasts target understanding of others (ToM, empathy) rather than self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Thus does not satisfy Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.
The analysis explicitly measures understanding of others' mental states (ToM) and emotional states (empathy), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others. Satisfies I1 and I2.

The contrast tests spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception—a social cognition task—so it meets both (I1) social-related task and (I2) measures social processing.

The task probes trait inferences and affective person knowledge, not affiliation/attachment or bonding (no measures of close relationships, cooperation, or kinship), so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
The analysis involves reception of facial information and affective/person knowledge tied to faces (face perception/characterization), meeting the social communication construct.
The study focuses on perception and inference about others rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for self-perception.
The analysis explicitly examines representations and inferences about others’ traits and emotions from faces, meeting both inclusion criteria for perception/understanding of others.

The contrast examines spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception—clearly a social-related task assessing social processing (perception/understanding of others and social cognition).
The task manipulates learned trait information and affective responses to faces, but does not measure affiliation/attachment, bonding, cooperation, or related constructs.
The analysis involves reception of facial information and implicit affective/trait communication from faces (face perception and affect recognition), meeting criteria for social communication.
The task probes perception/knowledge about others (traits/emotions) rather than self-related processes or self-judgment.
The contrast directly tests representations about others’ traits and affective states (disgust vs aggression) during face perception, satisfying perception and understanding of others.

The contrast examines retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception (faces associated with behaviors), a social task measuring social cognition and processing of others’ traits and emotions, so it meets I1 and I2.

The task probes trait inferences about unfamiliar individuals (aggressive vs disgusting) rather than affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship processes, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The analysis tests perception and interpretation of facially-presented social information (trait/emotion associations), which fits Social Communication (reception of facial communication), satisfying I1 and I2.
The contrast concerns perception and knowledge about other people (trait inferences), not self-related processes, so it does not satisfy Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

The analysis explicitly measures representations and inferences about others’ traits and emotions from faces (e.g., disgust vs aggression), directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Others, meeting I1 and I2.

The task is a social interactive paradigm (competitive reaction time task) involving observing and responding to another person (opponent). The contrast 'Receiving aversive stimuli; parametric modulation' measures anticipation of punishment and social interaction-related processing, satisfying I1 and I2.

The paradigm involves competition/cooperation dynamics (competitive reaction time task) and social bonding/interaction aspects; the contrast measures responses in a social competition context, meeting the affiliation/attachment task criteria.

The analysis involves perceiving social cues from an opponent (watching adjustment, anticipating punishment) and exchanging socially relevant information in a competitive interaction, meeting the social communication criteria.

The contrast focuses on anticipating aversive stimuli signaled by the opponent and observing the opponent, not on self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge processes. It does not satisfy the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The contrast measures perception and understanding of another’s emotional state (observing opponent suffering, intensity of pain), directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others (mental states, action/animacy perception).

The task is an interactive social aggression paradigm (competition, retaliation, observing an opponent) and the contrast measures social processing (retaliation and watching opponent), satisfying both I1 and I2.

The paradigm involves competition/cooperation dynamics (tit‑for‑tat), directly relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition), and the contrast measures these social bond/interaction aspects.

The analysis involves perception of the opponent (videos of suffering, facial/expressive cues) and interactive exchange, so it measures social communication (reception of facial/non‑verbal cues) meeting I1 and I2.

Although the task requires decision-making about one’s own action, the reported contrast focuses on social interaction and perception of the opponent; it does not specifically measure self‑related constructs (agency/self‑knowledge) required by I1/I2.
The analysis directly measures representations of others’ emotional states (watching opponent suffering) with parametric modulation by pain intensity (STS, amygdala), satisfying I1 and I2.

Task is an interactive social paradigm involving provocation, retaliation, and observation of an opponent — clearly a social processing task measuring social interaction and related processes (empathy, mentalizing).

The paradigm involves competition/cooperation dynamics (competitive reaction-time task, tit-for-tat adjustments) and measures social bonding/interaction elements related to affiliation/attachment (competition listed as relevant task).

Watching the opponent’s facial/vocal responses and adjusting behavior entails reception and processing of socially communicative signals (facial expressions, STS activation), meeting social communication criteria.

The contrasts focus on interaction with and observation of the opponent and on retaliation decisions; they do not primarily measure self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge, so Perception/Understanding of Self is not the main construct assessed.

The analysis explicitly examines observing the opponent’s suffering, empathy-related responses, and mentalizing (amygdala, STS, dorsal/ventral mPFC), directly assessing Perception and Understanding of Others.

Emotion recognition from faces is a social-related task that probes perception and interpretation of others' emotions, satisfying both social processing inclusion criteria.
Task involves emotion and age discrimination of faces, not measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding (e.g., kinship, cooperation), so inclusion criteria are not met.
The analysis measures reception of facial communication (emotion recognition), directly meeting Social Communication criteria.
The task assesses perception of others' emotions, not self-related judgments or self-awareness, so Perception and Understanding of Self criteria are not met.
Emotion recognition of faces directly assesses perception and understanding of others' emotional states, satisfying the annotation's inclusion criteria.

The AGE contrast involves implicit processing of facial stimuli (age discrimination), which is a social-related task involving perception of social cues from faces and thus measures social processing.
The task assesses age discrimination from faces and does not measure affiliation or attachment-related processes (no cooperation, kinship, or bonding contexts).
Although the task uses faces, it does not measure social communication (e.g., affect recognition, expressive exchange); AGE is an attribute judgment (age), not communication of social signals.
The analysis concerns perception of others (faces/age), not self-perception or judgments about one’s own state or traits.
Age discrimination is the perception and assessment of another person's trait (age), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

Task explicitly involves recognizing emotions from faces (explicit emotion recognition and implicit processing), which is social processing—meets both social-related task and measures social processing.

Task does not probe affiliation or attachment (no bonding, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts); it assesses emotion/age perception, so inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.
Explicit emotion recognition is reception of facial communication (affect recognition); the contrast measures social communication processes.
Task assesses perception of others' facial emotions/age, not self-related perception or self-knowledge; does not meet inclusion criteria for self-perception.
Emotion recognition of faces involves perceiving and understanding others' emotional states, satisfying criteria for perception and understanding of others.

The contrast compares communicative (social) speech vs description and manipulates familiarity; it targets social interaction and mentalization processes, so both I1 and I2 are met.

The analysis contrasts communication with a familiar versus an unfamiliar actor (analogous to loved one vs stranger/familiarity), addressing bonds/affiliation-related processing—satisfies the affiliation/attachment criteria.
Task requires production of communicative speech directed at another (production of social communication); the contrast isolates social communicative processes—meets both inclusion criteria.
The task and contrast target social interaction and understanding of others/familiarity, not self-related processing; inclusion criteria for self-perception are not met.

The communication vs description contrast and familiarity manipulation probe understanding of others' intentions, traits, and biographical information (theory of mind/mentalization), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast targets communicative speech and social interaction, engaging theory-of-mind and social-context processing; it is a social-related task and directly measures social processing (communication vs description).

The analysis explicitly contrasts familiar (close friend) versus unfamiliar actors and examines effects of familiarity during communication (familiar communication − unfamiliar communication), matching an affiliation/attachment (loved one vs stranger) type contrast.
The task is production of communicative speech directed at another (casually talking to an actor), i.e. social communication production; contrasts directly measure social communication.

The tasks and contrasts probe understanding of others and social interaction (theory of mind, familiarity) rather than self-related processing or self-judgments; does not meet Perception/Understanding of Self criteria.

The study investigates understanding others’ mental states, intentions, and familiarity effects (theory of mind, biographical information) during communication, meeting criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.
The task contrasts communicative speech vs description and involves social interaction, theory-of-mind processing, and familiarity—clearly a social-processing task.

The analysis includes a familiar (close friend) vs unfamiliar actor contrast (familiar communication − unfamiliar communication), matching a Loved one vs Stranger-type contrast assessing affiliation/familiarity.
The communication task explicitly measures production of socially directed speech (communicative speech) versus description, directly indexing social communication.
The contrasts and tasks probe understanding of others and communicative behavior, not self-perception or self-knowledge processes.

The study targets understanding others' intentions, biographical/familiarity information, and theory-of-mind-related processing (action and mental-state understanding), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast compares communicative vs descriptive speech and manipulates actor familiarity, directly probing social interaction and processing (theory-of-mind/interaction context). Satisfies social-related task and measures social processing.
The key contrast is familiar actor vs unfamiliar actor (friend vs stranger) during communication, which matches affiliation/attachment constructs (loved one vs stranger-type comparison).
The task requires production of communicative speech directed at an actor (production of social communication); the contrast directly measures social communication.

The analysis targets communication directed at others and familiarity effects; it does not probe self-related perception or self-judgment processes, so Perception/Understanding of Self criteria are not met.
The contrast and task probe understanding of others (theory of mind, biographical knowledge, action observation) and directly assess perception/understanding of others.

The task is a social interaction simulation contrasting responses to friends (positive peers) versus other peers/celebrities; it directly involves social processing. Both inclusion criteria are met.

The analysis contrasts responses to others (friends vs celebrities) and does not target self-related perception or judgments; it does not meet the self-perception inclusion criteria.

PD (Prisoner’s Dilemma) is an explicit social interactive task; the PD–Gamble contrast directly measures social processing and mentalizing (theory-of-mind) networks.
The task involves cooperation/competition and measures affiliative behavior (cooperation, camaraderie ratings, in-group vs out-group cooperation), satisfying affiliation/attachment criteria.
Prisoner’s Dilemma requires exchange of socially relevant information and reciprocal behavior (cooperation/defection), fitting the social communication construct and measured by the contrasts.

The study implicates default-mode and self-referential processes (simulation, DMPFC) during the social interaction; cooperation/competition is listed as an example task for this construct, so criteria are met.
The PD task and contrasts explicitly probe understanding others’ mental states (theory-of-mind, DMPFC/TPJ activity) and in-group/out-group mentalizing, directly matching this construct.

The analysis contrasts a social interactive task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) with a non-social Gamble task and explicitly examines brain networks supporting social interaction and mentalizing; it therefore measures social processing.

The PD game probes cooperation/affiliation and Experiment 2 explicitly tests in-group vs out-group affiliation, cooperation difference scores, and camaraderie ratings, so the analysis measures affiliation/attachment.
The task involves interactive exchange (cooperation/defection) and social information exchange between partners; contrasts and connectivity analyses target communication-related social processing.

Although the paper discusses default-mode regions and self-referential processes, the reported contrasts and primary analyses focus on social interaction and understanding others rather than explicit measures or contrasts of self-perception/self-judgment.

The analyses specifically examine theory-of-mind related regions (DMPFC, TPJ), mentalizing, and differences in responses to in-group vs out-group partners — directly indexing perception/understanding of others’ mental states.
Analysis uses an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma social task and tests neural responses to in-group vs out-group interactions, directly measuring social processing.
Task is cooperation/competition (PD game) and the analysis links cooperation difference (in-group − out-group) to BOLD differences, indexing affiliation/attachment-related behavior.
Prisoner’s Dilemma is a cooperative social interaction; the analysis examines neural correlates of interactive decisions (communication of cooperative intent) across groups.
The analysis focuses on responses to others (in-group vs out-group) and correlations with cooperative behavior, not on self-awareness or self-judgment per se.

Analysis probes neural differences when interacting with in-group vs out-group partners and correlates with behavioral discrimination, directly assessing understanding of others’ behavior/mental states.

The analysis compares neural connectivity during a social interactive task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) for in-group vs out-group partners, directly measuring social processing and group-based social cognition.

The contrast examines cooperation with in-group vs out-group partners (affiliation/attachment-related behavior) and reports related measures (cooperation difference, camaraderie), meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.

The task is a dyadic cooperative interaction (Prisoner’s Dilemma) involving exchange of socially relevant information and behavior (cooperation/defection), so it measures social communication processes.

Although DMPFC is related to self-referential processing, this analysis targets differences in connectivity when interacting with in-group vs out-group partners (mentalizing about others and affiliation), not an explicit measure of self-perception or self-knowledge.
The contrast targets mentalizing and understanding of others (in-group vs out-group interactions, theory-of-mind ROIs and connectivity), directly measuring perception and understanding of others.

Task is familiar/unfamiliar judgement of self, friend, and stranger using faces and names — a social-related task probing self- and other-processing. The contrast compares self vs friend across face and name, measuring social processing related to self/other distinction.

Contrast is self vs friend (self-specific activation). This does not test affiliation/attachment per se (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding measures) and therefore does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The task involves reception of facial information (face recognition) and written names — a social-communication receptive task. The contrast probes differential processing of socially relevant signals (self vs friend) across modalities.
The contrast explicitly compares self to friend (self-specific activation) across faces and names, directly measuring perception/understanding of self (self-recognition).

The reported contrast is self > friend (self-specific). It does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others; although other contrasts in the study examine friend>self, this specific analysis targets self-processing and therefore does not meet the inclusion criteria for perception of others.

Task contrasts self, friend, and unfamiliar persons using face and name recognition, which probes perception/understanding of self and others and social processing (self-recognition, familiarity, social interaction preparatory processes).

Contrast includes friend (personally familiar close friend) versus unfamiliar person and self, matching the 'loved one vs stranger' example and assessing affiliation-related familiarity/bonding effects.
The task involves reception of facial communication (face recognition) and name recognition; contrasts (self/friend/unfamiliar) assess social communicative processing and person recognition.
Directly tests perception/understanding of the self via self-face and self-name conditions and contrasts (Sf–Ff, Sn–Fn), satisfying self-related processing criteria.

Includes explicit contrasts involving others (friend, unfamiliar person) and probes representation and differentiation of others (friend vs unfamiliar vs self), meeting the criteria for perception/understanding of others.

The contrast compares self versus friend recognition (names), which is a social-related task probing perception/understanding of self and others and social processing; it therefore satisfies both I1 and I2.

The contrast (self-name vs friend-name) targets self-specific processing rather than affiliation/attachment between close others and strangers; it does not match the example contrasts (loved one vs stranger) or measure attachment per se.

The task involves recognition of socially relevant identity cues (names, and in the broader task faces), tapping receptive social-communication processes (identity recognition). The contrast probes social communication-related processing for names, satisfying I1 and I2.
The Sn–Fn contrast directly assesses perception/understanding of the self (self-name vs friend-name), meeting the criteria for self-related perception and judgment.

While the task includes perception of others, this specific contrast isolates self > friend (self-specific effect) rather than directly measuring perception/understanding of others (e.g., friend vs stranger). It therefore does not meet the intended criteria for an others-focused contrast.

Task involves familiar/unfamiliar judgments for self, friend, and stranger using faces and names—this probes perception/understanding of self and others and social processing (including preparation for social interaction). Contrast directly measures social processing.
Contrasts compare friend (close other) versus unfamiliar person (stranger) and self, which matches the example of loved one vs stranger and indexes affiliation/familiarity-related processing.
Face recognition and name recognition tasks probe reception of facial and person-related communicative cues; contrasts (self vs friend vs stranger) measure social-communication relevant processing.
Contrasts explicitly test self-recognition (self-face and self-name vs friend), directly measuring perception and understanding of self (self-knowledge/agency aspects).
Contrasts involve friend and unfamiliar person and examine neural responses to others (friend vs self vs stranger), meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.

Task requires familiar/unfamiliar judgments for self, friend, and unfamiliar persons using face and name stimuli; contrasts probe self vs friend and friend/self vs unfamiliar, which measure social processing (self/other perception, social interaction preparation).

Contrasts include friend vs unfamiliar (and self+friend vs unfamiliar), effectively comparing close/familiar person to stranger, which indexes affiliation/familiarity-related processing (analogous to Loved one vs Stranger).

Face and name recognition tasks probe reception of socially relevant signals (facial recognition and person identity) and contrasts (self/friend/unfamiliar) reflect social-communication-related processing (reception of facial/person cues).
Key contrasts explicitly test perception/recognition of the self (Sf, Sn) versus friend/unfamiliar, directly measuring self-related perception and self–other distinction.
Analyses contrast friend and unfamiliar persons and examine cortical responses to others (friend/unfamiliar), directly indexing perception and understanding of others.

Task explicitly involves social-related processing (self vs friend vs unfamiliar) using face and name recognition; the contrast measures social processing (self/other perception and social cognition).

The task involves familiarity and friend stimuli but is a recognition/familiarity judgment rather than a direct measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding or attachment measures). Contrast is friend>self, not a clear affiliation/attachment contrast.
The analysis examines face (and name) recognition and distinguishes responses to self vs friend, which relates to reception of facial/social communicative cues and social information processing.
The task explicitly includes self-face and self-name recognition and contrasts self vs friend, directly measuring processes of self-perception and self-related judgments.
The contrast involves friend (a familiar other) versus self and examines neural responses to others across modalities (face and name), measuring perception/understanding of others.
Task involves self- and other-recognition (self, friend, unfamiliar) using faces and names; the contrast (Ff–Sf) measures social processing (perception/understanding of self vs other).

Contrast compares friend versus self; although friend is socially close, the contrast does not directly operationalize affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger) or measure affiliation-specific constructs as defined.
The analysis uses face recognition (reception of facial communication) and contrasts friend vs self for faces, which falls under social communication (reception of facial information).
The task explicitly probes self-recognition (self-face/name) and the contrast involves the self condition (Ff–Sf), thus measuring perception/understanding of self.
The contrast compares friend (other) to self for face stimuli, directly assessing perception/understanding of another person.

The task is a familiar/unfamiliar judgment comparing self, friend, and unfamiliar persons using face and name stimuli. This is a social-related task probing perception/understanding of self and others and social-cognitive processes (e.g., preparation for social interaction), satisfying both inclusion criteria.

The analysis contrasts friend (a close, personally familiar person) with unfamiliar persons and self, which indexes affiliation/familiarity relationships (friend vs stranger). The task measures social bond-related recognition and includes the relevant contrasts (friend vs unfamiliar), meeting the inclusion criteria.

The experiment involves reception of facial (and name) communication and comparisons between self, friend, and unfamiliar persons; contrasts (e.g., friend vs stranger, self vs friend) probe social communication/perception, so both inclusion criteria are met.

The primary contrasts explicitly test self-recognition (self-face/name vs friend), directly measuring perception and understanding of the self (self-specific activation), satisfying the inclusion criteria.

The analysis includes contrasts assessing friend and unfamiliar person processing (friend vs self, friend vs unfamiliar), addressing perception and understanding of others and social-cognitive representations, fulfilling the inclusion criteria.
Task involves familiar/unfamiliar judgments of self, friend, and stranger across face and name stimuli, directly probing social perception and self/other processing.

Although the design includes friends and unfamiliar people, the task is a familiarity/self-recognition judgment rather than an explicit measure of affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or attachment).

The analysis uses face (and name) stimuli and contrasts that probe reception of socially relevant facial information and distinctions between self, familiar, and unfamiliar others, fitting Social Communication (reception) criteria.
The contrasts explicitly test self-recognition (self vs friend and self vs unfamiliar) for face and name stimuli, directly measuring perception and understanding of self.
Contrasts include friend and unfamiliar person conditions and test differential processing of others (friend vs self vs unfamiliar), addressing perception and understanding of others.

The task is social (familiar/unfamiliar judgments for self, friend, and stranger using faces and names) and the contrasts (self vs friend, friend vs self, self+friend vs control) directly probe social processing and self/other social cognition.
Contrasts compare friend (close other) versus unfamiliar person (stranger) and self, which indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing (loved one vs stranger contrast).
The task involves reception of facial (and name) social cues and comparisons between self, friend, and stranger, satisfying social communication measures (e.g., reception of facial communication).
The main contrasts test self-recognition (self vs friend, self-face specific activations), directly assessing perception and understanding of self.

Contrasts comparing friend and unfamiliar persons probe representations and understanding of others (friend vs stranger and differences in temporoparietal activation), meeting criteria for perception of others.

The contrast examines person recognition (self, friend, unfamiliar) during a familiar/unfamiliar judgment task and probes social-cognitive processes (self vs others, familiarity), so it meets both I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

The analysis contrasts familiar persons (self and friend) versus unfamiliar persons; the friend condition involves a close friend (social bond), and the contrast indexes familiarity/close-relationship effects similar to Loved one vs Stranger, satisfying I1 and I2.

The task involves perception of faces and names and judgments about person familiarity—forms of social communicative perception (reception of facial/name cues). The contrast measures social-communicative recognition, satisfying I1 and I2.

The specific contrast (S+F–2C) indexes familiarity common to self and friend relative to unfamiliar persons; it is not a self-specific contrast and does not isolate self-perception/understanding alone, so it does not meet the Perception/Self criterion.

The contrast includes friend and unfamiliar person conditions and identifies familiarity-dependent activation for others (friend vs unfamiliar), directly addressing perception/understanding of others; thus it meets I1 and I2.

Task involves recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar persons (face and name), probing self- vs other-processing and social cognition; contrasts (self vs friend, friend vs control, self+friend vs control) directly measure social processing.
Contrast includes friend versus unfamiliar (and self+friend vs control) which indexes familiarity/affiliation (close friend vs stranger), matching the example contrast Loved one vs Stranger.

Face recognition (and name recognition) of self, friend, and stranger engages reception of facial and identity-related social signals; contrasts compare friend vs stranger and self vs friend, meeting social communication criteria.
Primary contrasts explicitly test self-recognition (self vs friend, self-face specific effects), directly measuring perception and understanding of self (self-knowledge/agency).
Contrasts probe recognition of others (friend and unfamiliar person) and distinctions between them (friend vs self, friend vs control), addressing perception and understanding of others.
Task involves recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar persons using faces and names; contrasts directly probe social processing (self vs friend, friend vs unfamiliar).
Includes contrasts between friend (close other) and unfamiliar person (stranger), matching affiliation/attachment comparisons (Loved one vs Stranger).
Task involves perception of facial (and name) cues and comparisons between self, friend, and stranger, addressing social communication (reception of facial communication).
Contrasts explicitly test self-recognition (self-face, self-name) vs friend/unfamiliar, directly measuring perception and understanding of the self.
Contrasts examine friend and unfamiliar person recognition and friend-vs-self effects, measuring perception and understanding of others.

Task required familiar/unfamiliar judgments for self, friend, and unfamiliar persons using face and name stimuli—this directly probes social processing (perception/understanding of self and others). The contrast explicitly measures social processing (self vs friend).

The analysis contrasts friend (personally familiar) versus unfamiliar (control), which maps onto affiliation/attachment-related contrasts (loved one/familiar vs stranger). The task thus measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Stimuli include faces (reception of facial communication) and names; contrasts compare self, friend, and unfamiliar persons, addressing reception of socially relevant cues and person recognition—consistent with social communication.
The study explicitly probes self-recognition (self-face and self-name) and contrasts self versus friend, directly measuring perception and understanding of self.
The contrasts include friend and unfamiliar person conditions and assess recognition/familiarity of others, meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others (e.g., familiar vs stranger).
Task involves social-related judgments (self, friend, unfamiliar) and the contrast measures social processing (familiarity/self-other recognition across names vs faces).

Contrast compares familiar (self+friend) versus unfamiliar persons (controls) and thus indexes affiliation/familiarity (friend vs stranger-like comparison), meeting the affiliation/attachment criteria.

The task requires reception of person-identifying social signals (faces and written names); the contrast isolates name-based social recognition (non-facial communication), so it measures social communication.

Although the study addresses self-recognition, this specific contrast pools self and friend (Sn+Fn-2Cn) and contrasts name- vs face-related familiarity; it does not isolate self-specific perception/understanding, so it does not satisfy the self-specific inclusion.
The contrast includes friend versus unfamiliar person components (familiar vs control) and thus indexes perception/understanding of others (familiar vs unfamiliar), meeting the criteria.

The SELF task requires focusing on one's own emotional response to others' facial expressions (and the study investigates empathy), which is a social-related task and the contrast (SELF vs high-level baseline) measures social processing of emotion and perspective taking.
The task probes empathic emotional perspective taking (self vs baseline), not affiliation, attachment, or relationship/kinship-specific processes (no cooperation/attachment manipulation).

Stimuli are emotional faces and subjects make judgments based on facial expressions; the task involves reception/processing of facial communication and the SELF vs baseline contrast engages social-communicative processes.
The SELF-task explicitly requires attending to and judging one's own emotional response (self-awareness of internal emotional state), so the contrast measures perception/understanding of self.

The specified analysis is SELF versus high-level baseline, which targets self-related emotional responses rather than representations or judgments about others (OTHER-task would map to this construct, but not this specific contrast).
The OTHER vs high-level baseline contrast involves evaluating others' emotional states (empathy task), which is a prototypical social processing task.
The task probes emotional perspective taking/empathy for faces, not affiliation, attachment, or relationship-based bonding; it does not measure attachment/cooperation contrasts.
The OTHER task requires perception and evaluation of facial expressions (reception of facial communication), matching social communication constructs.
The specific contrast is OTHER vs baseline (evaluating others), so it does not measure perception/understanding of the self (SELF-task would).
The OTHER vs high-level baseline contrast explicitly measures understanding of others' emotional states from faces (Theory of Mind/emotion inference), satisfying perception of others.
Task involves empathy-related SELF and OTHER perspective taking and perception of emotional faces—clearly social processing.
The task probes empathy and perspective taking, not affiliation/attachment or bonding; does not measure attachment-related constructs.
Participants judge emotions from faces (OTHER-task) and respond to emotional expressions—this is reception of facial communication within social communication.
SELF-task explicitly asks subjects to report their own emotional response, meeting perception/understanding of self.
OTHER-task requires evaluating the emotional state expressed by faces, i.e., understanding mental states of others.

The analysis contrasts SELF-task (self-oriented emotional perspective taking) across genders, which is a social-related task (empathy, perspective taking). It clearly measures social processing of self/other emotions.
The task probes emotional perspective taking/empathy, not affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved vs stranger contrasts).
The paradigm requires perceiving emotional facial expressions and selecting descriptive emotional labels (reception of facial communication), so it measures social communication.
The contrast focuses on the SELF-task (subjects report their own emotional response), directly measuring perception/understanding of self (self-awareness of emotional state).

This specific analysis contrasts SELF-related activity between females and males (SELF_f vs SELF_m); it does not target perception/understanding of others (OTHER-task) so does not satisfy the 'perception of others' criterion.
Task directly probes empathy/emotional perspective taking (SELF and OTHER), which is a social processing construct involving perception and understanding of self and others in social interactions.
The task probes empathy and emotional perspective taking, not affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, close relationships, or kinship).

Task involves viewing eye stimuli and implicit monitoring of another's pupillary signals and their coherence with the observer — clearly a social-related task probing social perception and processing of others' states.
Task does not probe affiliation, attachment, bonding, or relationship-related processes; it examines pupillary signaling and social salience, not attachment.
Task assesses reception of facial/eye communication (perception of pupillary cues) and implicit social signal processing, fitting Social Communication (receptive facial communication).
Although participants' own pupil changes are recorded, the analysis focuses on perception of others' pupils and coherence effects rather than self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge measures.
The analysis directly measures perception and understanding of others' internal state via observed pupillary changes and responses in brain regions associated with social/emotional processing.

Task involves self-judgments and examines cultural modulation of self-representation (Perception/Understanding of Self), which is a form of social processing. The contrast measures social processing related to self-construal (I1 and I2 satisfied).

Although contextual items sometimes reference social context (e.g., ‘when talking to my mother’), the contrast IND > COL is about group differences in self-construal rather than a task specifically measuring affiliation/attachment (no explicit loved-one vs stranger or bonding measure). Does not satisfy the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The task probes self-knowledge (general vs contextual self-descriptions) rather than communication (reception or production of facial/non-facial communicative signals). Does not meet social communication inclusion criteria.

The analysis directly measures perception and understanding of the self via general and contextual self-judgments and relates neural responses to self-construal scores (satisfies both inclusion criteria).
The contrast focuses on self-judgments and self-construal rather than representations or judgments about others; does not satisfy perception/understanding of others criteria.

The task explicitly involves self-related social cognition (self-construal, self-judgments in social contexts) and the contrast measures social processing of self (individualism vs collectivism effects on self-representation).

The task examines self-construal and self-judgments (general vs contextual) rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although one contextual prompt references 'talking to your mother', the contrast targets self-representation, not attachment processes.

The paradigm does not involve exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals (facial/non-facial communication) but rather self-descriptive judgments; thus it does not meet Social Communication criteria.

The analysis directly measures perception and understanding of the self (general vs contextual self-knowledge) and examines neural correlates of self-construal, satisfying the Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.
The contrast focuses on self-judgments and self-construal rather than representations or judgments about others; therefore it does not meet Perception and Understanding of Others.
Task involves self-related social cognition (general and contextual self-judgments) which measures social processing of self-construal (individualism vs collectivism).
Although one contextual prompt mentions ‘‘talking to my mother,’’ the task assesses self-construal (self-knowledge) rather than measuring affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding per se.
The task does not involve reception or production of social communication (facial, vocal, or non‑facial communicative exchanges); it assesses self-descriptions.
The contrasts explicitly measure perception and understanding of the self (general vs contextual self-judgments) and use self-construal as a covariate, directly matching this construct.
The analysis focuses on self-judgments (general and contextual) rather than representing or reasoning about others' states or traits.

Analysis contrasts general vs contextual self-judgments, i.e., perception/understanding of self within social context; clearly a social-processing task. Satisfies I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

Although contextual items reference social context (e.g., 'when talking to my mother'), the contrast probes self-construal (general vs contextual self) rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding per se. Does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

Task involves self-judgments about trait descriptions, not communicative exchanges, perception/production of facial or non-facial signals, or other social-communication measures. Does not meet inclusion criteria.
The analysis directly measures perception and understanding of self (general vs contextual self-knowledge) and examines neural correlates of self-knowledge and self-construal. Satisfies I1 and I2.
Contrast focuses on self-related judgments (general vs contextual) rather than representations or judgments about others. Does not meet inclusion criteria for perception/understanding of others.
Task involves judgments about the self in social contexts (general vs contextual self judgments) and examines how cultural values modulate neural processing of self—meets social processing criteria.

Although one contextual prompt references 'when talking to my mother', the analysis targets self-construal (general vs contextual self-knowledge) rather than measuring affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding per se, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment task criteria.

The task assesses self-knowledge (general vs contextual) rather than receptive or productive social communication (e.g., facial/affective communication, gaze, or exchange of social signals), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
Directly measures perception and understanding of the self (general vs contextual self-judgments) and examines neural correlates of self-knowledge modulated by self-construal—meets criteria.
Analysis focuses on self judgments and self-construal, not on perceiving or reasoning about others’ states or traits, so it does not meet perception-of-others criteria.

The task involves self-judgments (general and contextual) and a contrast (contextual–general) correlated with self-construal (individualism/collectivism). This probes perception and understanding of the self—a social-cognitive process—so it meets both I1 and I2.
The task examines self-construal and self-judgments, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).
The analysis does not measure social communication (receptive or productive facial/non-facial communication); it focuses on self-knowledge judgments.

The experiment directly measures perception and understanding of the self (general vs contextual self-judgments) and the contrast assesses self-related processing as a function of self-construal, satisfying I1 and I2.
The analysis targets self-judgments rather than representations or judgments about others' states, traits, or intentions, so it does not meet inclusion for perception of others.

Task involves perception of emotional facial expressions and is explicitly about social/attachment signals; it measures social processing of others' emotions.

Although the study assesses attachment as an individual difference, this specific analysis (masked happy > neutral) is a main effect of emotional face perception rather than a direct measure/manipulation of affiliation or attachment.
Contrast measures reception of facial communication (happy vs neutral faces), meeting criteria for social communication (receptive facial communication).
Analysis concerns perception of others' facial emotions, not self-related processes or self-awareness.
Analysis directly measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states via facial expressions (happy vs neutral), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

Task involves viewing emotional facial expressions (sad, happy) and measuring neural responses; this is social processing (perception/response to others' emotions). Meets I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

Satisfies I1 (task/analysis concerns attachment-related processes) and I2 (measures affiliation/attachment).
The study assesses reception of facial communication (masked emotional faces) and neural responses, so it measures social communication (receptive facial communication). Meets I1 and I2.

The analysis examines neural responses to others' emotional expressions and correlations with attachment—this is perception and understanding of others (emotion/mental state cues). Meets I1 and I2.
Task involves perception of facial emotions and attachment-related individual differences—clearly social processing.
Analysis directly examines attachment avoidance (RSQ) and its relation to neural responses to social/affiliative signals (sad/happy faces).

Analysis concerns perception of others' facial emotions and attachment, not self-related judgments or self-awareness.
Analysis measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states via facial expressions and relates this to attachment avoidance.
Task involves perception of emotional facial expressions and examines attachment-related differences in social/emotional processing; directly measures social processing of others' emotions.
Analysis explicitly assesses attachment avoidance (RSQ) and relates it to neural responses, directly measuring affiliation/attachment processes.
Task assesses reception of facial communication (masked sad and happy faces) and neural correlates of emotion perception, meeting social communication criteria.
The analysis probes perception of others' facial emotions and attachment traits, not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge; does not meet inclusion criteria for self-related perception.

The paradigm probes perception of pain and agency, not affiliation, attachment, or bonding; no measures of close relationships or prosocial bonding are present.
Observers evaluate others' painful states and intentions (affect recognition/interpretation of social cues), so the contrast taps receptive social communication.
Although the study manipulates perceived agency, the specific contrast pain>no pain is a main effect across contexts and does not target self-related processing or agency judgments.
The contrast indexes perception and understanding of others' pain (representations of others' emotional states and actions), matching this construct.

Contrast (Self+Other > Self) explicitly manipulates presence of another person and perceived agency; the task examines social context/processing of others' pain and intentions, satisfying both criteria.

Task examines perceived agency and empathy for others' pain (including intentional harm), not affiliation, attachment, or positive social bonds; does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Stimuli require perception and interpretation of others' actions, intentions, and affect (receptive social cues), so the contrast measures social communication processes.

Although the design labels conditions as “self” vs “self and other,” the contrast targets processing of another agent and perceived agency rather than self-awareness, agency judgments about the participant, or self-knowledge; thus it does not meet perception-of-self criteria.
The contrast directly probes perception and understanding of others (their pain and intentionality); it satisfies inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.
The contrast compares trials with and without a second individual and assesses perceived agency and empathy for others' pain—this is a social-related task and directly measures social processing.
The task probes empathy and perceived agency/intentionality in harmful interactions, not affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes.
The paradigm examines perception of pain and agency/intentionality rather than explicit social communication (e.g., facial/expressive exchange or communicative signals).
Although labeled “self” in conditions, participants observed others' limbs and the contrast probes presence of another agent and perceived agency rather than self-awareness or self-monitoring.

The contrast directly manipulates presence of another person and intentionality, assessing representation and inference about others' actions and mental states (agency), meeting perception/understanding of others.

The contrast PCO>PCS tests perceived agency/social context (pain caused by another vs by self) and examines processing of others' actions and intentions; this is a social-related task and directly measures social processing.
The task contrasts intentional harm versus self-caused pain (perceived agency); it does not probe affiliation, attachment, or positive social bonding.
Stimuli involve perception of agency/intentional harm rather than communication (no facial/communicative exchanges); the contrast does not target social communication per se.

Although one condition involves self-caused pain, the PCO>PCS contrast is focused on perceived agency/others' actions rather than on self-awareness, agency judgments about one's own actions or self-knowledge.
The contrast directly assesses perception and understanding of others (intentionality/agency—pain caused by another vs by self), satisfying social-other perception criteria.
Task manipulates social context/perceived agency (self vs other) and the PPI contrast assesses context-dependent connectivity related to social processing, so both I1 and I2 are satisfied.

The contrast compares self versus other agency and the paradigm explicitly manipulates perception/understanding of others' actions and intentions, so it measures perception of others (I1 and I2).
The analysis correlates Emotion Contagion (a social-emotional trait) with brain responses while viewing pain stimuli (PCS trials). This measures social processing/empathy for others' pain.
The task and analysis probe empathy/emotion contagion and perception of others' pain, not affiliation, attachment, or bonding processes.
The analysis measures receptive social-affective processing (emotion contagion and perception of others' pain), which falls under social communication (affect recognition).
The analysis examines susceptibility to others' emotions during observation of pain in stimuli, not self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge.

The Emotion Contagion score correlated with brain activity during viewing of pain (PCS) reflects representations and assessment of others' emotional states—fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis contrasts pain caused by self vs pain caused by another and tests main effects and interactions of social context and perceived agency; this directly measures social processing (perception of others, social context/agency).
The task examines perceived agency and empathy for pain, not affiliation, attachment, or bonding processes; it does not measure affiliation constructs.
The study probes perception of pain and agency/intentionality rather than exchange of social information or communicative behaviors; it does not target social communication per se.

Although the design includes a ‘self’ condition (PCS), the focus is on perceiving others' pain and the effect of social context/agency rather than self-awareness or self-related agency judgments; it does not assess self-perception constructs.

The contrasts and reported results explicitly address perception and understanding of others’ pain and intentionality (PCO vs PCS, social context main effect, TPJ, mPFC, amygdala activations), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Analysis correlates individual emotional contagion (EC) scores with brain activity during PCO trials (pain caused by another), which directly involves social processing — perception and appraisal of others' pain and social context (agency).
The task probes empathy/agency and emotional contagion, not affiliation or attachment processes (no cooperation, kinship, or relationship-related contrasts).

The analysis concerns perception of others' emotional states (empathy for pain) and responses to social cues (presence/agency of another), which falls under receptive social communication (affect recognition).
The contrast and correlation focus on perceiving others' pain and trait emotional contagion, not self-related agency or self-knowledge judgments.
PCO trials involve perceiving and evaluating another person's pain and agency; correlating EC with PCO activity directly measures understanding of others' emotional states.
PCO trials involve viewing another person intentionally inflicting pain; this is a social task probing perception of others and empathy, so it measures social processing.
The task probes perception of harm/intentionality and empathy, not affiliation, attachment, cooperation, or close-relationship processing.
Stimuli involve perception of pain/intentionality without communicative signals (no faces, no explicit exchange), so it does not target social communication measures.
The analysis concerns ratings of others' pain (PCO) and perceived agency of another, not self-perception or agency judgments about the self.
PCO trials directly assess perception and evaluation of another's pain and intentionality (understanding others' states), satisfying this construct.

The contrast Movie scenes ToM > movie scenes PI directly targets Theory of Mind—inferring others' mental states—i.e., social processing. The task is explicitly social and the contrast measures social cognitive processing.

The task probes Theory of Mind/mental state reasoning rather than affiliation or attachment-specific constructs (e.g., bonding, loved-one vs stranger). Although the movie depicts social interactions, the contrast does not test affiliation/attachment per se.

The primary contrast targets understanding others' mental states, not self-perception or self-knowledge. Although authors speculate about self-referential processes in one component, the task/contrast does not explicitly measure perception or understanding of the self.

The contrast compares Theory of Mind (ToM) versus physical inference using a social cognition movie task (MASC). This directly probes social processing (inferring others' mental states).
The task and contrast probe mental state reasoning (ToM) and face/language processing, not affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding specifically.

The contrast measures understanding of others' mental states (ToM); it does not primarily assess self-perception or self-knowledge despite secondary self-referential activations.
The contrast explicitly targets understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind > physical inference), matching the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct.

The contrast compares Theory of Mind (ToM) vs Physical Inference (PI) on an MASC movie-based task assessing mental state inference about others—clearly a social-processing task. The MC answer ToM>PI contrast measures social cognition/processing.
The task assesses mental state reasoning (ToM) in social scenes but does not specifically probe affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding, cooperation).

The paradigm involves reception of social information (faces, emotions, dynamic social scenes) and explicit responses about others' mental states; the ToM>PI contrast indexes social communicative information processing.

The primary focus is on inferring others' mental states (Perception/Understanding of Others). While dmPFC/self-referential regions appear in components, the task does not directly measure self-perception or self-knowledge.

Task targets mentalizing/Theory of Mind and face/language processing rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, or relationship bonding (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one contrasts).
Task involves perception and interpretation of social cues including face processing and affect recognition; T-PICA identifies face-processing networks—fits Social Communication (reception) criteria.

Primary task measures understanding of others' mental states; although a component includes mPFC (interpreted as self-referential), the study does not explicitly measure self-perception/self-knowledge as the task focus.
The paradigm explicitly probes Perception and Understanding of Others (Theory of Mind) and contrasts ToM vs PI directly measure mental state understanding.

Task is an fMRI adaptation of the Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition (MASC) probing Theory of Mind; IC2 timecourse correlates with ToM conditions and shows ToM>PI effects, so it measures social processing.
The task measures mental state inference (Theory of Mind) and language/STS-related processing, not specific affiliation or attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one contrasts).
